intro: Acacia depressa, commonly known as the low acacia, is a small shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often prostrate stems and small, bipinnate leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, which are followed by flat, pod-like fruits. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, showing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Acacia depressa is often used in landscaping for its hardy nature and ornamental appeal.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive, often thorn-like structures and small, globular flowers. Its species is Acacia depressa, a specific type of acacia known for its low-growing habit and is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions.

This species thrives in coastal and inland regions, often growing in shrublands and woodland habitats. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range. Acacia depressa plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for local wildlife.
